instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
A bit of history. Customer spilled ice tea on his keyboard and the only way it would power on was by plugging in the mag charger. I changed the keyboard then put the board into the ultrasonic cleaner, rinsed in alcohol and left to dry out.

Now I only get green then orange light on the charger but no fan spin. CPU does not warm up.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is reading as 12.56V. Have checked ALL power rails for short to ground but found none.

WTF have I done. Please help

Thanks

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> voltage level.
Any history available?

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: I'll get those voltages for you later as I've just rinsed the board out again with alcohol - sorry. No other history than that already mentioned. When I attached the keyboard the board seemed to respond to an SMC reset i.e. charger light went green for a second then back to orange,

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
MagSafe light should stay amber without battery.
That is not an issue...

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Yes I know. I was just letting you know that it responds to SMC reset as I thought that would give you a little more to work with. I'll get you those voltages as soon as I can if not tonight (it's 10:30PM in London) then tomorrow. Really appreciate your help. Thanks again. M

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Morning
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.34V
<SIGNAL>M_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 0.035V (on <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR>) (other pin of <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>PP3V_S5</SIGNAL> reads 3.34V)
<SIGNAL>M_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = 3.38V

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
"(P)<SIGNAL>M_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 0.035V"
PCH will not start in this way; it requires 3V there.
Did you try original Apple charger?

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: BATLOW being low is your problem you're not using an original OEM charger. Get a KNOWN GOOD 85 watt magsafe 2 for testing!! Also, fan will not spin on this model until the CPU really heats up, so do not look for fan spin look for CPU VCore and an image on the screen.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:

Yes I'm aware of the fan spin delay and also that the CPU should warm up (it doesn't). No display when screen attached.Thanks

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: These will have issues with the magsafe 2 converters I would still say the charger is suspect because of that. Especially because the S4 Rails are missing as well as <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>. Where was the original corrosion? There is a chance it needs to go through the ultrasonic a second time if the first time didn't get all of the corrosion. What is your resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Most of the corrosion was near the CPU but it was pretty gunky all over. I've already put through the ultrasonic again to be sure but no change. I've asked my customer to drop over his MS2 charger tomorrow. In the meantime resistance to ground for <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 9.57 Kilo Ohms - reading taken from pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR>. Thanks

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Did it even turn on before ultrasonic? If not, I would get your CPU is dead due to liquid near it and the controllers. If it did, def go with the MS2 charger next.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Yes it did John. This is from my first post "A bit of history. Customer spilled ice tea on his keyboard and the only way it would power on was by plugging in the mag charger. I changed the keyboard then put the board into the ultrasonic cleaner, rinsed in alcohol and left to dry out.

Now I only get green then orange light on the charger but no fan spin. CPU does not warm up.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is reading as 12.56V. Have checked ALL power rails for short to ground but found none."

Thanks

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Anything I can be doing in the meantime?

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Hmm ok. First thing to try would be the charger. If that doesn't produce VCore, then this one might suck a little bit. I suspect their is a chance it was not quite dry under the CPU/RAM/any of the BGA chips, and it might need a second cleaning. <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is one of the sleep signals that enables the PCH to turn on, and it comes directly from the SMC. Usually, when that is missing, we have seen the 2015 boards refuse to put it out if the charger is not 100% the correct OEM charger it needs. It is also possible that something could be pulling it down or not creating it (SMC, CPU etc). This can sometimes happen due to crap under the CPU/SMC as well.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Oh boy. It's already had a second clean. OK I'll try the charger and post back once I've tried it out. Thanks again

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Gotcha please do. If the charger doesn't fix it, then this could be so many things.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: I have got a brand new 45watt magsafe 2 charger here I tried but no joy so I'm guessing it would have to be 85w. I'm so sure it's not the charger but we shall see. I'm just not that lucky!

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: His battery was pretty charged last time I checked when the machine was working. What if I plug in just the battery and keyboard. Should I be able to power up that way and would that prove it's more than just the charger?

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Yes if it starts from a charged battery, then that would mean likely just a charger issue not autostarting the machine. 45 watt won't work btw only works with Airs.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: I plugged in the battery and screen and the 85w charger with adapter and the fan is now spinning. Waiting a minute or two before switching off as the CPU/ Heatsink was very hot to the touch. Didn't wait for apple folder as was worried about the heat from CPU. Do they normally get really hot to the touch. Shall I do it again but this time plug in the SSD?

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Better still and external USB flash drive don't want to lose the guys data

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: I'm getting the Apple Logo and it's booting from my test USB in High Sierra. There was corrosion on pin 1 of the LCD cable. So just need to fit the board in fully with keyboard etc or shall I wait for the customers adapter first to see if the board will work without battery? I need to test if it will power up with just battery and keyboard and I'll report backThnx again

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Yes, they will get pretty hot, but it is something to monitor to make sure the temp goes back down. You do have a heatsink on it correct? If so, boot the Mac, and see if all works (keyboard, booting etc). Also, run HWMonitor to monitor if the CPU cools down should run normal around 50-60 celsius on this model. Appears you will def need a magsafe 2 85 watt for the future.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: I've ordered an OEM magsafe 2 adapter. Should be here soon. I'll get back to you once it arrives. thnx. M

NOT adapter, buy charger...

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
OK so the MagSafe 2 charger arrived earlier today but I'm still getting the same problem. If I plug the battery in and the MagSafe the MacBook loads fine. Well I say fine - sometimes you hear the chime and get display and other times you only hear the chime and get NO display (I don't mean no back light I mean no display). 

Where shall I go from here?

Thank you
M

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
So you always get backlight, just image missing sometime?
Do you get black or white screen that time?
External video OK?
Did you try other LCD screen?
Clean LCD connector and cable terminal.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: How can I check to see if I always have backlight? It's black screen - no video no backlight as shining a torch shows nothing. Have checked the LCD connector and the plastic that separates pin1 (<SIGNAL>PPVCOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>) from the back of that cable seems damaged. I'm attaching a picture of the end of the LVDS cable. I don't have another screen for this model. External monitor does not work either when the internal does not work. When the internal work so did the external.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
"I don't mean no back light I mean no display"
Like telling has backlight, missing image only...

Pufff, your LVDS cable is f***d; it must be changed.
Pin 1 is exactly backlight line, <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>.
I bet you get short to ground when move it; that is the time when backlight is gone.
BTW, do not power the board when check there in diode mode...

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: mmmm I see. I'll have a quick look on youtube regarding changing the LVDS cable. I hope it's not a nightmare to do!  On a separate question - Why would the machine only power on when both magsafe and battery are attached?

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: You are probably using an incorrect (45W?) charger...

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Another question if I may? If the logic board is working fine and I plug in an external display but disconnect the LVDS cable should I get a picture on the external monitor? Thnx M

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Disconnect LCD, connect external monitor and give it time to enter into OSX.
Maybe will not send external video before loading OSX...

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A

Ok will try and see what happens
many thanks M

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
OK so here is the current situation.
Screen is working it was just a bad cable.

Here is what is happening so far....

If the battery is plugged in and I plugin the charger, MacBook Powers up. If the battery is not plugged in and I plug in the charger it will NOT powerup.(even when pressing the power key)

However, It will power up without the battery if I startup by passing the SMC.

Any suggestions please?

Thanks again for all your help so far.

M

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: This still sounds like a non genuine charger...this is exactly what happened to me when I started doing figuring it out. Does it charge and run off of the battery?

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: It?s a genuine charger. It shows the charging icon but doesn?t appear to charge - but keeps the battery at 68%. Kept it plugged in and the battery level didn?t increase nor decrease

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Post voltage for pins 9 & 15 of <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.
Also post exact volatge for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (battery connected and not)

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Yeah then your charging circuit is suspect if that's the case. Tried known good battery? Post exact voltages as 2informaticos explained. Also check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the ISL

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>
Pin 9    = .035 V
Pin 15  = .067 V
Resistance between pins 17/18 = 3.8 Ohms
Resistance between pins 27/28 = 20.5 Ohms

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.56 V (Without battery)
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 13.01 V (With Battery)


Don't have a good battery to try.

Thnx

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
SCL/SDA voltage and diode mode to ground.
I recommend to try your battery with other board too.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
SCL and SDA seem to be jumping around within the range 3.43 to 3.33 V. So I get 3.43 one second then 3.33 / 3.39 /3.34 /3.41 etc
These readings are without battery.
SCL  0.499 V Diode Mode
SDA  0.497 V Dode Mode
I'm sorry but I don't have another board.
Thnx M

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Pulsing SCL/SDA could be sign of I2C signals from SMC.
In this case, the battery is first suspect.
Don't waste more time, untill get a known good battery to test.
Just post <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> voltages, charger w/ and w/o battery connected

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Should there be pulses on SCL/SDA or should it be a constant voltage and if constant what voltage should I expect to see? 3.43?
Also were the diode measurements I gave you a good sign or bad sign?
If we put the battery aside for now why do you think I don't get fan spin with no battery and just charger unless I bypass the SMC?

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Ooops, still not starting from charger only?
Are you 100% sure using original Apple charger 85W?
Of course no fan, as normal behaviour on this board.
Fan spins later, after CPU gets hot.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Yes proper charger
yes I know about the fan not spinning until cpu warms up
you didn?t answer my questions in my last post?? Well? I need you super skills of deduction :)

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Proper test of I2C protocol for SCL/SDA lines can only be done with o-scope.
Should see something like in attachment.

Diode mode on SCL/SDA lines shouldn't show more than 1% difference for a good board; in fact is likely less than 0.5%.

"why do you think I don't get fan spin with no battery and just charger unless I bypass the SMC?"
You just told being aware of no fan spin at start.
On SMC bypass mode is normal that fan spins at max from start.

threads.title: MacBoo Pro Early 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: Sorry I don't have an oscilloscope.
